learning_obj.text: Understand the basic concepts of Monte Carlo simulation and why it’s useful
Set up a Monte Carlo model, running simulations with common tools (Excel, R, Python, or specialized software), and interpreting the outputs (mean, range, percentiles, probability of certain outcomes)
Apply method to their own projects to make better decisions with uncertain variables

characteristics.text: Probabilistic, not deterministic → Uses random sampling to explore a range of possible outcomes rather than a single estimate
Iterative → Runs hundreds of simulated “trials” to build a distribution of results
Flexible → Can be applied to timelines, budgets, outputs (e.g., number of beneficiaries), or other uncertain variables
Scenario-based → Works well with best-case, worst-case, and most-likely inputs
Graphical outputs → Usually visualized with an S-curve (cumulative probability graph) or histogram

process.text: Pick a distribution → Usually Triangular or PERT (uses those 3 estimates to model uncertainty)

sub_bullets.text: Randomly pick a value for each task from its distribution
Add them up to get total project cost/time for that simulation

process.text: Collect results → You get many total project values (like 1,000 possible outcomes)

sub_bullets.text: Y-axis = probability of finishing by that time
Find dates with 50%, 80%, 90% probability of completion
Use this to set realistic deadlines and buffers

benefits.text: Captures uncertainty realistically → Reflects real-world variability
Improves decision-making → Helps practitioners understand probabilities and make informed, transparent commitments
Versatile → Can be applied to scheduling, budgeting, and risk analysis
Supports communication → Probability graphs are intuitive visuals to discuss plans with funders, partners, and other communities
Focuses on Worthwhile development → Development decisions are sustainable and equitable by revealing which choices minimize environmental harm and reduce inequality under uncertain conditions

drawbacks.text: Requires quality input data → Poor or unrealistic estimates can lead to misleading results
Some statistical literacy needed → Users need basic understanding of Excel and statistics to set up and interpret correctly
Can be time-consuming → Setting up sometimes takes time, especially for complex projects with many variables
Tool access → May need Excel add-ins, statistical software, or programming knowledge
Doesn’t eliminate uncertainty → It models uncertainty, but it doesn’t guarantee the future outcome

example.text: An international NGO is planning to build a rural primary health clinic in a remote community. The goal is to provide basic healthcare services, including maternal health and vaccinations, to around 5,000 people in the area. The project budget is tight, and timelines are influenced by uncertain factors like weather, material supply, and regulatory approvals.

sub_bullets.text: Repeat for each major cost category
Randomly sample costs from each category’s distribution
Sum to get a total project cost for each iteration
Build a distribution curve of possible total costs
Mark Base Cost, Management Reserve, and Final Cost
Shade the contingency zone, budget risk, and business risk areas

evaluation.text: Can you run the simulation correctly on Excel?
Can you plot a probability curve and assess the x and y intercepts?
Can you interpret min/max and what that means for your project?
